comment.author: 90207601@N07
comment._content: The Frederick Ash Building is there on Hunter Street, so the photo must later than 1905.  You can also see the new Fred Ash building (now demolished) , so sometime after 1927 when the new Fred Ash building was constructed.  You can also see the old Northumberland Permanent Building Society building at the corner of Burwood and Hunter streets.  This building was demolished in 1938.  The date for the photograph must be between 1927-1938.

comment.author: 64403351@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90207601@N07] It can be narrowed down a bit more. At the far right on Hunter Street is a double decker bus (just behind the tram!). Newcastle got its first buses in 1935 and the body shape would suggest it is a 1936 Leyland Titan.

comment.author: 18754343@N00
comment._content: Segenhoe Apartments built 1936 so later than that. And The Moorings built 1935.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Great! Thanks [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90207601@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/davidbromage] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/dukpix] - we've suddenly gone from no date to a very narrow date range with your help.
AB

comment.author: 78690340@N07
comment._content:
Newcastle City Hall & clock tower
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/6047538211/]

location of City Hall:  151.772 degrees East  32.928 degrees South

Time on the City Hall clock 3:40? - same on both faces so probably right
end of shadow  of clock tower near northern alignment of Tyrrell Street, on western side of Darby St

height of tower (scaled from plans)    44m 
Length of tower shadow: 150 - 160m

so sun is 15.4 - 16.3 degrees above horizon

direction of sun from shadow angle  of clock tower: 308 degrees (+/-2 degrees)

If the clock time is 3:40 the best fit for date is late July

comment.author: 59233855@N03
comment._content: Your photograph would have been taken in 1936-37 prior to the sale of the former rail block of land from Civic train station to Worth Place along Hunter street. By the look of it there may have been a billboard across the road from the Civic theatre precinct near the rail cross over point west of Civic train station. It may have been placed there by these companys prior to auction www.flickr.com/photos/uon/5854929964/ Also there would have been a land acquisition time frame prior to sale as was seen with the Honeysuckle land aquisition at a later date The land along Hunter street was still under use by the Department of Railways in 1929 as this photograph will show www.flickr.com/photos/uon/6068306540/ Hope this helps and best of luck finding the actual date..

comment.author: 59233855@N03
comment._content: Also the side view (6 windows) of the building to the left of the Nesca power station is the former Woodland hospital on the corner of Church & McCormack st

comment.author: 78690340@N07
comment._content: Two more aerial photos from Photo Investigator, over the same area & taken between 1929 & 1938, but not on the same flight as this photo ( different time of the year as well?) looking SW over Civic towards Merewether investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... looking NW from over The Hill towards Carrington investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 59233855@N03
comment._content: 199 King street (The Moorings) and also 124 Church street apartments were built in the 1938 period stated page 26, last paragraph in this link. pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/126270/20110331-1416/www.newcastle...

comment.author: 78690340@N07
comment._content:
I have compiled a montage of 3 photos from the Bert Lovett collection in the Uni of Newcastle archives, taken in late1934 from the City hall clock tower & looking over the centre of this photo. 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/78690340@N07/8208185240/]

The railway land along Hunter Street has not been cleared, and the photo shows the buildings and wharfs on the "Dyke End" before the State Dockyard was constructed.
